| PHP 5.2.2 and 4.4.7 Released                                       |
|   from the hot-off-the-presses dept.                               |
|   posted by CowboyNeal on Friday May 04, @21:25 (PHP)              |
|   http://it.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/05/04/2156256           |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

daeg writes "PHP [0]5.2.2 and [1]4.4.7 have been released with a plethora
of security updates. Many of the security notifications come from the
[2]Month of PHP Bugs effort, and range from double freed memory to bugs
in functions that allow attackers to enable register_globals, to memory
corruption with unserialize(), to input validation flaws that allow
e-mail header injections, with an unhealthy sprinkling of other bugs and
flaws fixed. All administrators that run any version of PHP are
encouraged to update immediately."

| Some Schools Ending Laptop Programs                                |
|   from the great-expectations dept.                                |
|   posted by CowboyNeal on Friday May 04, @22:50 (Education)        |
|   http://slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/05/04/222217               |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

The New York Times reports that [0]schools are abandoning their
laptops-for-students programs. It turns out that the expense of providing
laptops, expense of repairing laptops, difficulties of school network
management, and discipline problems stemming from pornography, cheating,
and cracking more than outweighed the educational benefits. Indeed, a
number of schools have concluded that far from improving student
achievement, laptops either had no effect or actively hindered academic
performance. Apparently, politicians embracing technology as a quick fix
for social problems doesn't always work out.

Discuss this story at:
    http://slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/05/04/222217

| Harvard Law Professor Urges University to Fight RIAA               |
|   from the you-know-you-want-to dept.                              |
|   posted by CowboyNeal on Saturday May 05, @02:56 (The Courts)     |
|   http://yro.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/05/05/0413249          |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]NewYorkCountryLawyer writes "Distinguished Harvard University Law
School Professor Charles Nesson has [1]called upon Harvard University to
fight back against the RIAA and stand up for its students, writing
'Seeking to outsource its enforcement costs, the RIAA asks universities
to point fingers at their students, to filter their Internet access, and
to pass along notices of claimed copyright infringement. But these
responses distort the University's educational mission. ...[W]e should be
assisting our students both by explaining the law and by resisting the
subpoenas that the RIAA serves upon us. We should be deploying our
clinical legal student training programs to defend our targeted
students.'"

| Astronomers Again Baffled by Solar Observations                    |
|   from the back-to-the-drawing-board dept.                         |
|   posted by CowboyNeal on Saturday May 05, @05:28 (Space)          |
|   http://science.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/05/05/0421244      |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

SteakNShake writes "Once again professional [0]astronomers are struggling
to understand observations of the sun. ScienceDaily reports that a team
from Saint Andrew's University announced that [1]the sun's magnetic
fields dominate the behavior of the corona via a mechanism dubbed the
'solar skeleton.' Computer models continue to be built to mimic the
observed behavior of the sun in terms of magnetic fields but apparently
the ball is still being dropped; no mention in the announcement is made
of the electric fields that must be the cause of the observed magnetic
fields. Also conspicuously absent from the press releases is the
conclusion that the sun's corona is so-dominated by electric and magnetic
fields because it is a plasma. In light of past and present [2]research
revealing the electrical nature of the universe, this kind of crippling
ignorance among professional astrophysicists is astonishing."

mattnyc99 writes "In his weekly tech column for Popular Mechanics, Glenn
Derene [0]predicts that everyone will have a home server to network their

productivity software useless. As prices for products like [1]HP's
MediaSmart Server drop and as processing power becomes more pervasive,
Derene says, 'you'll ultimately need a centralized server\u2014that
high-powered traffic cop\u2014to coordinate the non-stop exchange of

| What's The Greatest Web Software Ever?                             |
|   from the lynx-versus-links dept.                                 |
|   posted by CowboyNeal on Saturday May 05, @11:06 (Software)       |
|   http://slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/05/05/1259218              |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

An anonymous reader writes "[0]What's The Greatest Web Software Ever
Written?, Charlie Babcock of InformationWeek asks, in his follow up to
last year's widely read list of [1]greatest software period. The winner
then was BSD 4.3. The new Top 12 list is a little funky in that it
doesn't distinguish between apps, sites, and controls \u2014 XMLHttpRequest
object set \u2014 is one of the winners. It includes many of the usual
suspects, like Digg and AIM, along with some unexpected winners. (like
World of Warcraft) The number one choice however, Apache server, is
arguably correct."

| Brazil Voids Merck Patent On AIDS Drug                             |
|   from the developing-world-revolt dept.                           |
|   posted by kdawson on Saturday May 05, @13:19 (Patents)           |
|   http://yro.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/05/05/1633207          |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]JoeBackward writes "Merck has this useful anti-AIDS drug Elfavirenz,
and Brazil has lots of poor people with AIDS. So, after trying really
hard to get Merck to cooperate on pricing, the [1]Brazilian government
has decided to take a 'compulsory license' to the patent, and get the
drug from a factory in India. This compulsory license is basically a way
to take the patent by eminent domain." This move gives [2]Brazil one more
thing in common with [3]Thailand, both of which have blocked YouTube.
Thailand's [4]compulsory licensing of Elfavirenz and Plavix has landed
the country on the US's [5]watch list for piracy.

| Microsoft, Best Buy Face Racketeering Suit                         |
|   from the one-way-to-sign-up-customers dept.                      |
|   posted by kdawson on Saturday May 05, @14:28 (The Courts)        |
|   http://yro.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/05/05/1735259          |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

15 judges of the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals have unanimously
[0]reversed dismissal of a RICO class action suit against Microsoft and
Best Buy, which claims the companies engaged in fraud in promoting
Microsoft's MSN online service. ([1]RICO is a statute originally intended
to help prosecutors go after organized crime.) Quoting: "The case started
after James Odom bought a PC-based laptop at a Contra Costa County Best
Buy store. Data about the purchase was sent to Microsoft as part of a
joint marketing agreement between the companies. Microsoft then signed
Mr. Odom up for its MSN Internet service and, after a free trial period,
began billing him for it." Howard Bashman's How Appealing blog has
[2]more details on the reversal, including a paraphrase from one of the
appellate judges that "all blame rests with the U.S. Supreme Court for
allowing the 'outlandish' result that a claim such as this can be pursued
under RICO."

| TJX Breach Began With WEP Crack                                    |
|   from the pwn3d-by-Pringles dept.                                 |
|   posted by kdawson on Saturday May 05, @15:33 (Security)          |
|   http://hardware.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/05/05/1812254     |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

An anonymous reader sends us to the Wall Street Journal for a detailed
report on [0]what is known to date about the TJX data breach. It seems
that the loss of over 45 million credit card numbers and more than
450,000 SSNs, driver's license numbers, and military identifications
began with someone using a "telescope-shaped" antenna at a wireless link
at a Marshall's near St. Paul, Minnesota in July 2005. The link was
encrypted using WEP, which had been [1]known to be broken since 2001. The
crackers who got into the TJX central databases are believed to be
Romanians or Russians with ties to the Russian mobs. The eventual cost of
the TXJ fiasco could exceed $1 billion \u2014 not including the numerous
lawsuits filed against the retailer.

| Does Linux "Fail To Think Across Layers?"                          |
|   from the one-advantage-of-the-cathedral dept.                    |
|   posted by kdawson on Saturday May 05, @16:44 (Linux Business)    |
|   http://linux.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/05/05/1844215        |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

John Siracusa writes a brief article at Ars Technica pointing out an
exchange between Andrew Morton, a lead developer of the Linux kernel, and
a ZFS developer. Morton accused ZFS of being a "rampant layering
violation." Siracusa states that this [0]attitude of refusing to think
holistically ("across layers") is responsible for all of the current
failings of Linux \u2014 desktop adoption, user-friendliness, consumer
software, and gaming. ZFS is effective because it crosses the lines set
by conventional wisdom. Siracusa ultimately believes that the ability to
achieve such a break is more likely to emerge within an authoritative,
top-down organization than from a grass-roots, fractious community such
as Linux.

Discuss this story at:
    http://linux.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=07/05/05/1844215

| Webcomic Author Deemed a Terrorist Threat                          |
|   from the now-that's-just-silly dept.                             |
|   posted by kdawson on Saturday May 05, @17:55 (Censorship)        |
|   http://yro.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/05/05/1913245          |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

CaptainCarrot writes "Writer/IT contractor [0]Matt Boyd, formerly the man
who made up the words for webcomic [1]Mac Hall and who now does the same
for his and Ian McConville's new comic [2]Three Panel Soul, was recently
[3]fired from his government job. His conversation with a co-worker about
a gun he intended to buy for target shooting was overheard by someone in
a nearby cubicle. As it was unfortunately the day of the [4]Virginia Tech
shootings, the eavesdropper panicked and reported him to management. That
was bad enough. But when he [5]used the comic to document the meeting
where the reason for his firing was explained, he was [6]visited by
representatives of local law enforcement investigating him on suspicion
of making a "terroristic threat" using the Internet. No charges have been
filed. Yet. FLEEN [7]interviewed Matt about the incident."

|   from the coming-to-their-senses dept.                            |

|   http://politics.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=07/05/05/2218241     |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

[0]remove office writes "After calls from several prominent bloggers and
a couple of presidential candidates, CNN has agreed to [1]release the
footage from its upcoming June presidential debates uncopyrighted.
Senator Barack Obama was the first candidate to [2]call for all
presidential debates to be released under Creative Commons, with fellow
Democratic hopeful John Edwards [3]following shortly afterwards. CNN will
be the first to do so with their June 3rd and 5th Democratic and
Republican debates. MSNBC hosted the first presidential debates recently
but [4]refused to release them under Creative Commons, opting instead to
post online only [5]commercial-ridden clips in Windows Media format."
